content:
=== Game Rules ===
Game rules in natural language:
Here’s a plain‐language breakdown of what’s going on in the game:

• Genre and Overall Feel
 – It’s essentially a space shooter arcade game. You control a spaceship (the avatar) that can fire missiles (using the “sam” bullet) while enemy aliens, which drop bombs, are spawned from hidden portals. The setting is outer space with a planetary base you need to protect.

• Game Mechanics
 – You have an avatar (a spaceship) that can shoot missiles. These “sam” projectiles travel upward.
 – There’s a stationary “base” (a planet image) that stays in place. It seems to be a key asset since if it’s hit by enemy bombs it’s destroyed.
 – Enemies appear as aliens that can drop bombs. They are spawned from two kinds of portals (“portalSlow” and “portalFast”) that create different types of aliens. The aliens move, adjust directions when they reach the screen edge (a “turnAround” rule on EOS), and occasionally drop bombs.
 – The various objects interact in specific ways. For example, if a missile (sam) hits an alien, the alien is removed and you gain score points (+2). But if your spaceship collides with an alien or a bomb, or if a bomb hits your base, you suffer a penalty (often losing the ship or base or deducting points).

• Objective and Win/Loss Conditions
 – The primary objective is to fend off and eliminate the aliens spawned from the portals while protecting your base.
 – You lose if your avatar (your spaceship) is destroyed (i.e. the sprite count for avatar goes to 0).
 – You win when both the enemy aliens and the enemy portals have been entirely eliminated (the “MultiSpriteCounter” condition: when there are 0 portals and 0 aliens left).

• Overall Strategy
 – Keep moving and avoid collision with enemy aliens and their bombs. Since a direct hit by an alien or a bomb not only costs you in points (score penalties) but may also destroy your ship, evasion is as important as offense.
 – Aim and time your shots carefully. Your missiles (sam) are effective against aliens, adding positive score when you land a hit. Focus on taking out the aliens before they can drop bombs on your base.
 – Be aware of your base’s safety. Since bombs that hit the base will kill both, prioritize intercepting enemy bombs if possible.
 – Monitor the portal spawn points. Since these spawn new foes, eliminating aliens quickly will eventually lead to shutting down or emptying these portals, which is your win condition.
 – Balance risk and reward: aggressive shooting can increase your score considerably (each alien hit gives you points), but if you’re too reckless and let aliens or bombs come too close, you risk losing your lives or your base.

In short, the game calls for agile movement, precise shooting, and constant vigilance to protect a key asset (your base), all while picking off waves of aliens spawned from enemy portals. Mastering these aspects and managing your positioning is key to reaching the win condition.

You are an intelligent player playing a video game, and you have a friend provide you strategy. Interpret the state, rule, strategy and act accordingly. Notice that your avatar position is one of the most important information, if the position doesn't change from the last state, you need to analyze the state and make a different action from the last time.

=== Available Actions ===
0: ACTION_NIL
1: ACTION_USE
2: ACTION_LEFT
3: ACTION_RIGHT

=== Important Mechanics Notice ===
 In some games, directional actions (LEFT, RIGHT, UP, DOWN) may first cause the avatar to rotate toward the intended direction without immediately moving. If the avatar's position does not change after a directional action, it may indicate a rotation has occurred. To proceed, you must apply the directional action again after rotation. Always verify whether the avatar actually moved after each action. Please understand the rule and the interaction set first, then locate the item, finally choose a meaningful action towards the win and respond in the format: ``` Action:<action number> ```. Include one sentence of feedback on the action and your expectation to see if it aligns with the strategy. Notice, Action 0 will not reasult in any change in this game environment, and you may need to understand the level layout first to play the game.

Action:2

I'm moving left again to further align my ship with the aliens at the top left, expecting to eventually be in a position to shoot them vertically.

=== Sprite Mapping ===
avatar -> 'a'
background -> '.'
background base -> '0'
background portalSlow -> '1'
background portalFast -> '2'
alienBlue -> '@'
base -> '#'

Action:2

I'm moving the ship further left in hopes of aligning it with one of the aliens at the top left, so that when I fire upward, the missile has a better chance of colliding with an enemy.
